intro: Brassica rapa var. briggsii, commonly known as field mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm and has alternate, pinnately lobed leaves that are usually hairy. The plant produces yellow flowers in clusters, which are followed by long, slender pods containing rounded seeds. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its cross-shaped flowers and aromatic, often pungent, foliage. Field mustard is often found in disturbed soils and can be a weed in agricultural fields.
